title: February 27
description:
Dean and Lucie were back at their desks this week, but Felix and Milo had another week of vacation.

They went to the Centre de Loisir, the city-run day camp. Milo was practically in tears when Lucie dragged them there Monday but it went surprisingly well. There were friends from school, and the activities were a hit -- especially the many field trips to parks, the gym, an art exhibit and a theatre play.

children.title: Tour TDF
children.description:
The distinctive 140-meter tall Tour TDF towers over Les Lilas and can be seen from very far away, including from the 325-meter tall Eiffel Tower. Built in the mid-80's, it is the home of various radio and TV transmitters. TDF means "TéléDiffusion de France".

It rises dramatically over the Centre de Loisir, where the kids went every day this week. As we walked past once, Felix explained to Milo:


F - You see Milo, all the TV shows we watch go thought this tower.
M - Even Beyblade and L'École de Ninjas ?
F - Yes, Milo, all of them.
M - Wow! They make Beyblade up there!?!
F - No, no, the show is made somewhere else; just the TV waves go through here.
M - Oh, okay.

children.title: Batboat
children.description:
Monsieur Dassault (chairman of the eponymous French military conglomerate) always parks interesting knickknacks in front of his hôtel particulier on the Rond-point Champs Elysées.

Last time it was a fighter jet; this time, Batman and an (actually quite lame) amphibious Batboat.

Our Robins stopped by for a quick Kodak moment on our way to the Palais de la Découverte.

children.title: Animal Magnetism
children.description: Dean experiences goatee envy at the Palais de la Découverte.

children.title: Electro Magnetism
children.description:
Felix has a passion for electromagnetism, of all things. And, of all things, the Palais de la Découverte offers hour-long kid-friendly seminars on the subject.

It had it all: massive electromagnets, an enthusiastic geeky instructor and a gigantic lightning-spewing Tesla coil. We couldn't have asked for more!

children.title: Graffiti Wall
children.description:
We took another graffiti safari in our neighborhood. These are from same street artists who painted our school's courtyard.

We came armed with our little pamphlet and dutifully identified each artist.

children.title: Big Faces
children.description:
The Centre de Loisir took Milo's group to an exhibit about these street artists, where he got to stencil some graffiti himself!

Felix was extremely envious: he's itching to paint a mural and has been sketching ideas in a little notebook. If we weren't living in a borrowed house for the year, we would have turned him loose on a wall in the garden by now.

children.title: Rero
children.description: It says "I would have preferred a white wall..."

children.title: Grafpower
children.description:
"No retirement for graffiti artists"

Yeah, take THAT, striking teachers!

children.title: Tintin
children.description: Our graffiti-hunting expedition uncovered a cute little playground we hadn't noticed before. We liked the Tintin-inspired moon rocket.

children.title: Madeleine
children.description:
Madeleine and family came over for and end-of-the-winter-vacation supper.

THEY had gone skiing, too. It's de rigeur.

children.title: Marché
children.description:
Slice of our life: every Sunday morning Les Lilas has a big open market of fruits and vegetable.

Actually, it's not really open. It takes place in a large "halle", a sort of big warehouse to protect the stalls from the weather.

children.title: Cheese
children.description: There's a lot more than fruits and vegetables at the market. This is also the place to shop for meat, cheeses, fish, saucissons, used books, winter hats and all sort of things.

children.title: Goodbye Cruel World
children.description: Please observe a minute of silence for Dean's hard drive that died this week. R.I.P.
